item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1010 (Drafts counted as published entries) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: list_authors() function lists also authors who have written only a drafts, but no published posts. This is problem only for new authors. However, also number next to authors name (if shown) includes drafts even though they are not readable to anyone.

item.title: Ticket #1009 (Optional title in comments_popup_link) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1009 (Optional title in comments_popup_link) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
The comments_popup_link function in wp-includes/comments-functions.php does not currently permit to submit a title tag for the hyperlink; it is assumed that the text of the hyperlink will be self-explanatory. But some templates (see ​http://www.somefoolwitha.com/) use uninformative titles, and need a title tag. Could this be added as a last argument to the function?

Patch attached.

item.title: Ticket #1008 (metaWeblog API enhancements for WordPress - enclosure support) updated
item.dc:creator: canopus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1008 (metaWeblog API enhancements for WordPress - enclosure support) created
item.dc:creator: canopus
item.description:
I attach a patched xmlrpc.php (only a few lines of code added).

This is for metaWeblog API enhancements including:

  • enclosure support in metaWeblog.Newpost, using own WordPress postmeta table system (line 847)
  • base64 decode for files saved from metaweblog.Newmediaobject (line 542)

With this, WordPress would be the first CMS capable of automatic podcasting publication from Podcast client software, like EasyPodcast.

  • canopus -

item.title: Ticket #946 (comment moderation requests for entries with comments disabled) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Just reading through this as I originally had this problem as well (see the support forum) and dmd seemed to be the only person who had exactly the same thing happening. They were definitely comments (not trackbacks) awaiting moderation and comments were ALL closed (I checked the database). However mine have now mysterioulsy stopped too. I'll let youy know if I get any more.

(On my blog both "Allow Comments" and "Allow Pings" were and still are set to off for all posts (pasts and future).

I'm just writing this to confirm that dmd isn't (or wasn't) the only one!

tomsusweb

item.title: Ticket #1003 (Some template tags add "h2", some don't) updated
item.dc:creator: lyklev
item.description:
Thank you for bringing up the subject again. You are not the first; I reported it as bug 896 and now I see that it was reported even before me as bug 818, where it was decided that it was not going to be fixed.

I really think it is a bug, since it is very inconsistent and clashes with the design-content separation philosophy. It is also the only h2 in the entire directory.

Good time to get rid of this h2 once and for all. It *will* keep coming up.

item.title: Ticket #1007 (do_action & arguments) updated
item.dc:creator: dasher
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1007 (do_action & arguments) created
item.dc:creator: dasher
item.description:
do_action doesn't accept arguments by ref and the newly created args array isn't returned - which makes it hard for hooks to modify arguments or change passed arguments.

It'd be useful if something like the following was possible:

$args = array('varA'=>$varA); do_action('some-action', &$args); $varA = $argsvarA?;

item.title: Ticket #1005 ([optimization] update_post_caches() unnecessarily includes posts table ...) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1005 ([optimization] update_post_caches() unnecessarily includes posts table ...) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1005 ([optimization] update_post_caches() unnecessarily includes posts table ...) created
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description: In wp-includes/functions.php, the function update_post_caches() appears to unnecessarily include the posts table in the SQL statement. The function already has a list of post IDs ($post_ids, assembled from passed in $posts) for which to find matching $wpdb->post2cat.post_id rows to update the posts category cache (what this SQL is there for).

item.title: Ticket #1004 (A less privileged user's post 'disappears' after they make an edit) updated
item.dc:creator: raena
item.description:
Patch changed
  1. I tested this by creating a user with level 1 and submitting a draft.
  2. I then logged in as the admin to publish it. The post appeared on the site as you would expect.
  3. I logged in again as my level 1 user and made an edit to the post, and clicked 'Save.' I did not alter anything about the post (including its status).

3a. It is worth noting at this point that neither Draft nor Private radio buttons were selected. I did not alter this either.

  1. Having saved this edit, the post was still visible under the list on the 'Manage > Posts' page, but had disappeared from the site at this point.
  2. I logged in again as the admin. The post was not visible in the list of posts in 'Manage > Posts.'

Fixing it:

  1. I could log in again as the level 1 user and see the post in the list, as though it was still published.
  2. Making one more edit resulted in the Draft button being correctly highlighted. Once this was done, the post behaved normally.

item.title: Ticket #1004 (A less privileged user's post 'disappears' after they make an edit) created
item.dc:creator: raena
item.description:
When a user with level 1 submits a draft for review, and that post is published by someone with a higher level, that user can then go back and make edits.

However, when the edit is made, the post disappears from the site and is unviewable by another user.

item.title: Ticket #1003 (Some template tags add "h2", some don't) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1003 (Some template tags add "h2", some don't) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Some template tags, such as "get_links_list" automatically insert "h2" tags on the titles with no way to override. Other template tags, like "wp_list_cats" do not.

All template tags that return a title should be consistent and allow the title to be overridden, even allowing no title to be displayed.

item.title: Ticket #988 (warning returned in mw_newPost) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
More proper fix would be to change "if ($catnames)" into "if (is_array($catnames))", since checking twice is useless. Lines 526 and 579 want this fix.

Why the error occurs: WP receives a post with no categories, and tries to loop through the categories.

item.title: Ticket #901 (apply_filters's handling of extra arguments is broken) updated
item.dc:creator: michel v
item.description:
Uploaded a version of the patch that doesn't handle the :X addition.

So, long story short: to accept more than one argument, one must specify a fourth argument to add_filter() and add_action().

item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1000 (Text doesnt wrap for <Previous Entry> <Next Entry> links at top of template) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
​http://www.alexking.org/software/wordpress/themes/blog/2005/02/27/theme-competition/

In that link, as you can see, the previous and next links ( Â« WordPress 1.5 Released with Theme Support Theme Competition Rules Â» are not on the same line.

IMHO, this does not look very nice.

I'd say the expected behavior would be for each entry (previous, next) to wrap to a new line, instead of extending past it's border, and making the next entry go to the next line.

function wp_mail($to, $subject, $message, $headers = ) {

if( $headers == ) {

$headers = "From: " . get_settings('admin_email') . "\n";

}

this worked for me.

item.title: Ticket #972 (No "save and continue editing" for pages) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
No, that's not what I mean. I missed 0000657 on my pass through mosquito, but this is not a duplicate of 0000485. I am not talking about a draft. I am talking about publishing the page, but being able to make more changes immmediately. This is analagous to regular word processing and saving the document regularly.

I don't understand why this can't be done, as all it would require is a normal save with an added redirect back to the page in question's edit screen.
